journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering

title-group.article-title: Novel probabilistic dynamic safety metric formulations for flight path determination

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, University of California Davis, USA

author-notes.corresp: Nesrin Sarigul-Klijn, Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, University of California, 2132 Bainer Drive, Davis, CA 95616, USA. Email: nsarigulklijn@ucdavis.edu

abstract.p: This article details a novel method for the determination of safe flight paths dynamically following an in-flight distress event. The method is based on probabilistic safety metrics which also include the touchdown and evacuation/rescue phases after landing. Two case studies simulating in-flight distress events, one from the west and the other from the east coast are presented using these formulations for a quantitative analysis. It is found that the nearest landing sites are not always the safest ones showing the benefits of the newly developed safety metrics. Finally, the path safety levels are plotted as a function of mission safety probability values using innovative polar plots that provide useful information to pilots.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The ultimate goal in trajectory re-planning, following an in-flight distress event is to achieve safe landing with zero casualties and no additional vehicle damage. The time scale for the events following a distress event is depicted in Figure 1. This task leads to three unique difficulties.
How to properly represent an uncertain scenario with unknown information and unpredictable human decision?
How to decipher and make use of sensory data to represent vehicle’s heath condition?
How to integrate context information for stochastically optimal path planning?
Figure 1.
Distressed aircraft event time scale.

Distressed aircraft recovery technique (DART) research team at University of California, Davis is working on flight trajectory generation to maximize safe outcome probability (MSOP) after an in-flight distress event. This article details the safety metrics developed for DART flight trajectory optimization to MSOP architecture. This probabilistic flight path generation method includes an abort airport as well as aircraft dynamics and is based on the safety metrics approach developed under National Aeronautics and Space Administration’s (NASA) Integrated Resilient Aircraft Control (IRAC) project program funding.

There are four algorithms in DART–MSOP architecture as shown in Figure 2 and further details can be found in the references.1–14 These four algorithms are: (a) low-fidelity initial turn algorithm; (b) high-fidelity paths with aborts; (c) guidance of a perpetual turning attitude aircraft to maneuvre to land safely, and (d) decision making. DART–MSOP is based on integration of four new algorithms developed that maximizes safe outcome probability after a distress event by incorporating an abort airport together with a model of current aircraft dynamics. The first new algorithm, a statistical-based initial turn determination algorithm, is developed to advise pilots to a reachable best landing site immediately after the distress event and prior to using the second new algorithm, a high-fidelity flight trajectory generation algorithm. A third new algorithm determines the flight maneuver for guidance of a perpetual turning attitude aircraft to fly the trajectory generated by the second algorithm. The third algorithm is only used if the aircraft has stuck controls or a similar malfunction that generates a non-zero amount of bank angle and causes the aircraft to turn only in one direction. As a three-dimensional (3D) high-fidelity algorithm, the second algorithm considers the probability of an abort to increase the overall survivability by minimizing the expected flight path length as it shapes the trajectory. The fourth algorithm is the decision support for human or autopilot and is based on Dempster–Shafer evidence theory. Figure 2.
DART–MSOP architecture safety metric Phases 1, 2 & 3.

In summary, although there has been research by others in the area of aircraft trajectory generation as reviewed below, our DART–MSOP architecture is unique, in that it uses probabilistic-based safety metrics and considers the entire mission as opposed to the in-flight section only. One other novelty of DART–MSOP is that it is applicable to any aerial platform: remotely controlled aerial systems (R-CAS), autonomously controlled aerial systems (A-CAS), and hybrid controlled aerial systems (H-CAS). The performance of this newly developed probabilistic trajectory algorithm and the safety metrics are evaluated using numerical simulations that include variable failure rates throughout the trajectory to simulate different in-flight distress conditions, and a hypothetical in-flight distressed aircraft in east and west coasts of USA.

There are other approaches in the literature for emergency trajectory generation. Atkins et al.15 and Atkins16 detail an adaptive flight planner approach as an online trajectory generator with variable autonomy. It is intended to enhance the flight management system with improved cockpit situational awareness. Implementation of this approach can be fully autonomous or include pilot decisions. Flight plans are defined as waypoints and connecting segments with feasible trim states. Landing sites are selected after determination of the aircraft’s reachable footprint and ranked according to numerous features including runway width/length and current wind/weather conditions.

A temporally dependent probabilistic model is used for plan development in Blackmore.17 A user specifies event probabilities and action delays which allow computation of state probabilities. State probabilities are used to choose goal paths and remove improbable states. LaVelle18 and Sarigul-Klijn et al.19 use a direct multiple shooting approach to give the optimal open-loop trajectory. The trajectory is inverse simulated via the integration inverse method. The trajectories are compared. If the error between the trajectories is unacceptable, the optimization and inverse simulation parameters are adjusted. Otherwise, the trajectory is considered near-optimal and realistic.

Sharma20 and Zengin and Dogan21 develop trajectories for unmanned vehicles under safety, time and/or fuel consumption constraints. The trajectory problem is challenging for two main reasons. First, the optimization problem is non-convex. Second, there are a number of sources of uncertainty in the problem, such as damage and modeling uncertainty, disturbances, and uncertain localization. There are two popular representations of uncertainty that have been applied to geometric motion-planning problems. One representation restricts parameter uncertainties to lie within a specified set. A motion plan is then generated that is based on the worst-case analysis. This representation is referred to as non-deterministic uncertainty. The other popular representation expresses uncertainty in the form of a posterior probability density. This often leads to the construction of motion plans through average-case analysis.22,23

In summary, DART–MSOP architecture is the only approach available which uses probabilistic-based safety metrics and considers the entire mission safety as opposed to the in-flight section only dynamical. “Probabilistic-based safe paths architecture” section of this article details the overall architecture followed by “Formulation of probabilistic dynamic safety metric (p-DSM)” section, which gives the details of probabilistic safety metric formulations. The next section covers probability model, followed by abort rose polar plot-based representation section, and finally the numerical case studies and conclusions are presented.

sec.title: Probabilistic-based safe paths architecture
sec.p:
Flight path planning in the presence of an in-flight distress event has many requirements. First, the preplanned flight path becomes unsustainable, the pilot has to re-compute a path and next fly it to an alternate landing site, which the pilot must also find and evaluate in the midst of the emergency and most often in a very short time (Figure 1). The tasks include aircraft health assessment, landing site search, and flight path prediction while flying an off-nominal aircraft. In addition to high-stress environment, this workload is likely to cause errors and may yield accidents due to pilot overload. An important insight to the safety problem following a distress event is to recognize that landing the aircraft alone is not enough. The landing is not complete until all life forms are off the aircraft and taken into a hospital, as needed. Hence, the phases to a successful landing are identified as depicted in Figure 2 and defined as follows.
Phase 1. En route-flight/approach to landing. This encompasses the time from the distress event until the aircraft touches the runway. One of the contributors to further failure here is time in the air. The longer the aircraft spends flying, the more likely it is that something else will fail. Further maneuvers, weather, issues with structural damage and control failures, among others, also contribute. However, all the parameters must be considered for overall mission safety.
Phase 2. Touchdown/landing rollout/full stop. This covers from the time the aircraft touches the runway until it stops sliding or rolling. At this point, failure is a function of runway environment and approach speed. Specifically, the area beyond the runway is important in the event that the aircraft cannot slow within the length of the runway or overshoots the desired touchdown location.
Phase 3. Evacuation/rescue. This covers from the time that the aircraft stops until all the injured forms are taken into a hospital. The primary issue here is the proximity of fire crews, ambulances, and hospitals.

In the case of an in-flight distressed aircraft, the common practice is to land at the nearest airport. The basic assumption behind this airport selection method is that distance is the overriding factor in the relative safety of any given set of flight plans. One major assumption is that only fully functional airports should be considered. If this were not the case, a minimum distance strategy would dictate an immediate descent and landing wherever the aircraft intersects the ground. Thus, the suitability of a given landing site depends on a myriad of factors. Typically, a heuristic approach is used to limit the number of potential landing sites to those that meet a set of standards, such as a functional airport and sufficient runway length. A flight plan is then created to land at the nearest of these permissible airports. While this is a very effective, simple, and straightforward method, it does have one significant shortcoming: it does not account for a progressive failure or a continuous range of desirability for a given airport. A good example is a fuel leak. It is difficult to predict the rate at which the fuel will be lost, especially if there is a chance of more leaks, or uncertainty about the reliability of the fuel level sensors. Under such a condition, the range prediction may not be accurate.

Let us consider the airport selection problem where there are multiple airports nearby, with varying sets of facilities. Aircraft over even sparsely populated areas will have several opportunities for landing, all with varying characteristics such as distance to distress event position, flight maneuvers required to reach the runway, runway characteristics of length, width and heading, fire and emergency crew presence, size and capability, proximity to hospitals, and weather conditions. All these factors as well as the level of experience of the pilot contribute to the overall safety of a given flight plan. It would be helpful to have a way to evaluate flight plans that would account for these factors without needing an experienced pilot on the cockpit. This new architecture has two major departures from the common strategy for emergency planning. The first is the consideration of all factors of the flight plan, from event to successful landing using three phases (Figure 2). This subject will be discussed further in the following section. The second is that it attempts to dynamically predict and account for changes in the planned landing site.

The first item above is essentially an attempt to formalize what pilots are expected to do when developing an emergency flight plan. The pilot looks at the available landing sites and their respective characteristics, and makes a judgment call as to which site to attempt to land at, and how best to get there. DART–MSOP architecture attempts to take that process and automate it by introducing more mathematical formalism and reducing guesswork. This will reduce workload on the pilot and provide a contingency plan for inexperienced pilots. It also has extensive application to any aerial platform; R-CAS, A-CAS, and H-CAS.

The direct flight path following the distress event is represented by a connection between the distress event position and the safe landing site as recommended by our safety metric algorithms which also include sets of potential safe abort landing sites along the path, as depicted in Figure 3. “Landing site” is a general term which includes any airport or “off-field” location. Since the aircraft could land at various directions at a landing site, one has to include the landing direction influence in the safety metric. There are innumerable outcomes to a flight plan. For example, the aircraft can successfully land at the nominal landing site, or at any of the potential abort sites. This grows to an infinite number of outcomes because the decision to abort can happen at an infinite number of points along the path to the nominal landing site. Since there is a unique path for each abort decision, and an infinite number of abort decisions, there are an infinite number of potential paths. Each of these paths will naturally have a unique level of safety. Hence, a measure of the overall mission safety of the flight plan must be capable of predicting the average safety of each possible outcome (nominal landing with each possible abort path and landing) weighted by the probability of that outcome occurring. In the most general case, every possible landing site must be considered as nominal, with the set of possible abort sites equal to all other airports in range. Figure 3.
DART–MSOP architecture with multi-fidelity 4-algorithms designed.

There are three possible outcomes.
A successful landing at airport B, the better airport, as illustrated in Figure 4.
A successful abort to airport A, the abort airport.
More than one abort airport along path included in preplan, as illustrated in Figure 5. Figure 4.
Flight ground track with abort at Airport A.
Figure 5.
Generated paths due to moving abort decision points.

There are two statistical components in developing a “p-DSM”. The first one is the measure of the safety of the in-flight phase of the path (phases 1(a) and (b) in Figure 2). For this study, the measure of safety used will be related to the length of the path. During the flight, if no further distress conditions are developed as time progresses, the shortest path will be the safest. This only refers to the flight portion of the plan and the possibility of a further airport being safer still exists when weighing in the phase 2 and phase 3 parameters.

In order to find the average safety of all the possible outcomes, the probability of each outcome must be available. Ideally, the model would be based on abort decision criteria applied to a set of random decision variables, resulting in the probability density of an abort and which other airport to abort to for any position along the nominal path. For this study, the entire abort decision model and random decision variables will be initially integrated into a single-probability density function. This reduces the complexity of the path safety problem significantly while still remaining sufficiently close to real scenarios. An individual probability of successful completion of each phase is used. The associated probabilities for phases 2 and 3 will simply be estimated in the case study no. 1. A more sophisticated calculation of these probabilities in phases 2 and 3 will be formulated in the last section. From this point, the path safety equation can be numerically implemented and solved using numerical optimization techniques.

sec.title: Formulation of p-DSM
sec.p: In this section, a quantitative treatment of the problem will be developed. Since all the phases must be completed successfully for the mission to be successful, the three probabilities of success for that phase of the flight plan multiply to form the overall probability of success. Hence, the probability of safety for a given path is (1)D=P1*P2*P3

Since any valid flight plan must end at a landing site, for N landing sites, there will be N valid flight plans. Each plan has a local maximum safety; therefore, all plans can be evaluated and the best can be chosen.

Recalling the definition of an average, the probable safety of each flight plan is (2)Dave=Dnom*Pnom+∑abort pathsDi*Pi where Dnom is the safety of the nominal path, Pnom the probability that the nominal path is the one that will occur, and Di and Pi the equivalent for each of the potential abort paths. This is the safety of each outcome, multiplied by the probability of the outcome, summed over all the possible outcomes.

It would be useful to parameterize the set of potential abort paths in a more mathematically tractable fashion. It is recognized that for any point along the path, there is at most one abort landing site that makes sense and beyond a certain point, no feasible abort sites are available. The second case occurs at the point along the path that the nominal path is shorter, hence safer, than all the possible abort paths. Therefore, the set of possible abort paths with the distance along the path where the abort decision is made are parameterized. That makes it possible to write the equation above as a set of integrals with finite limits. Rewriting (3)Dave=Dnom*Pnom+∑i=0sites∫∫SiDig(sg)*Pig(sg)ds

Note the change in the domain of the summation. Instead of the infinite set of possible abort paths, it is now the finite set of possible abort sites. Here, Si is the portion of the nominal path in which i is the best abort site. In other words, this is the domain on which an abort to i is valid. The border between the feasible abort domains for i and j is the locus of all points for which (4)Di=Dj

Essentially, this defines the locus of all points for which the safety of the two flight paths are the same. These 3D surfaces form the transitions between ideal abort locations. Hence, the points at which the nominal path pierces the surface are the limits of integration for the integrals above.
Solving the problem is a matter of applying optimization algorithms (DOT) to each group of airports to compute the overall safety of each flight plan.
A useful result that will be used later is as follows (5)Pnom+∑i=0sites∫SiPig(sg)ds=1

This condition must hold for any probability model that is to be used to solve this problem. This ensures that the average safety is a true average. Interestingly, this does not assume that the valid abort domains do not overlap. This result also allows Pnom to be computed from the abort model, which is useful when the abort probability model has an infinite or semi-infinite domain, as integrals with infinite limits do not lend themselves to numerical integration.

sec.title: Probability model
sec.p: The above derivations are general since there was no assumption made for either the probability distribution or the safety metrics. From here on, those are chosen and the problem is worked into a solvable form. As mentioned above, the complexities of abort decision criteria and random decision variables will be rolled up into a single-probability density function; in this case, the Weibull distribution. This distribution was chosen because it represents failure well and has excellent shape flexibility. Second, the safety metric must be chosen. It contains three parts as noted above, one for each phase of the flight plan. The other requirement on the safety metric is that it should be a true probability. For that reason, the Weibull distribution is used again, this time using different shape and size parameters, since it is modeling a different phenomenon. The previously discussed abort probability model (called the “abort model”) attempts to model the probability of having to change the target landing site mid-flight. The second (called the “failure model”) attempts to model the probability of an outright failure during the flight phase. Both are modeling failures, just of different types.

sec.title: Probability of P1 phase safety
sec.p: The 3D high-fidelity representation algorithm uses a unique matrix representation that dispenses with trigonometric functions for most of the computations, improving computational speed.1
The governing equations are derived using the models chosen. Starting with the definition of the nominal safety (6)Dnom=P1,nom*P2,nom*P3,nom

The model of the flight phase safety can be inserted in this way (7)Dnom=Wfg(Lnomg)*P2,nom*P3,nom where Lnom is the length of the nominal path and Wf() the cumulative Weibull distribution for the failure model. Next, the safety of the path with an abort occurring at a distance s into the nominal path and terminating at the ith abort location is given (8)Dig(sg)=P1,ig(sg)*P2,i*P3,i
Similar to the nominal derivation, the failure mode can be inserted (9)Dig(sg)=Wfg(Lig(sg)g)*P2,i*P3,i
Lig(sg) is the length of an abort path which was defined in the previous section.

Moving one step up, it can be shown that the average-safety equation with the Weibull distribution is the abort probability model (10)Dave=Dnom*Pnom+∑i=0sitesDig(sg)*wg(sg)ds where the various safety terms are as described above, and w(s) is the Weibull probability density function. Equation (10) can be rearranged to get an analytical result for Pnom and inserted above (11)Dave=Dnom*g(1-∫Swg(sg)dsg)+∑i=0sitesDig(sg)*wg(sg)ds where S is simply the entire domain on which an abort can probably occur. This does assume non-overlapping abort domains; however, this is a reasonable restriction and it makes the equation easier to work with. The equation is now in a form that can be numerically evaluated and optimized by changing the shape of the nominal path.

sec.title: Probability of runway (P2) safety
sec.p: The probability of successfully completing the rollout phase of a flight plane can be modeled as the aircraft sliding on the runway. A simple and illustrative method is to model the aircraft as a point mass with anisotropic friction on the runway. The definition of failure in this case is leaving the runway before stopping. Given the model, if the aircraft leaves the runway, it stays off the runway, so the aircraft has left the runway (failed) if and only if it stops off the runway. Another way of putting it is if the aircraft stops on the runway, it is certain that it never left the runway. Hence, the entire process does not need to be modeled as a Markov random walk, as would be the case if the process noise is included. Only the ground roll distance needs to be computed.

During landing, the rolling friction coefficient will be very high, due to the use of brakes. The drag could also be much higher if speed brakes or a drag chute is used. It is also possible for the aircraft to use thrust reversal to shorten the touchdown.24 Equation (12) yields the acceleration for the aircraft, assuming that the runway is level (12)a≈-gWg[-T+D+μrg(W-Lg)g] where W,T,D, and L are the weight, thrust, drag, and lift, respectively, and μr the rolling friction coefficient. The ground roll distance can be solved with the integral (13)Vstall=2*WρSCL,Mmax (14)V0=1.15*Vstall (15)Xstop=X0+∫V00VadV where Vstall is the stall speed, CL,Mmax the maximum coefficient of lift, V0 the touchdown velocity, and X0 the touchdown position.

The drag and lift on the aircraft during landing can be represented by (16)D=CDq¯S=g(CD0+CL2μAReg)q¯SL=CLq¯S where CD0 is the zero lift drag coefficient, µ the dynamic viscosity, AR the aspect ratio, e the efficiency factor, and S the planform area. The dynamic pressure is equal to: q¯=12ρV2. Combining equations (12) to (15) yields (17)Xstop=X0+∫V00V-gWg[-T+D+μrg(W-Lg)g]dV=X0+∫V00Vg(-gW[-T+CD(12ρV2)S +μr(W-CL[12ρV2]S)]g)dV
Completing the integral gives the final version of the ground roll distance (18)Xstop=X0+WgρSg(CD-μrCLg) ×lng[1+g(CD-μrCLg)ρSV02g(-T+μrWg)g]

A similar derivation applies to the transverse direction. The Weibull distribution is once again used to find the probability that the aircraft will end up off the runway in phase 2. The range of the Weibull distribution is found from subtracting the length of the runway by the ground roll distance. This is essentially how much extra runway the pilot has in each direction. The distribution size parameter for the Weibull is the touch down velocity that is unique to each plane. Once again, the goal was to determine parameters that were unique to each given aircraft. Using the touchdown velocity makes sense, because if it is very high, then there is a greater chance of the pilot undershooting or overshooting the desired landing zone. This means that there will be a higher λ and therefore, a more spread out distribution, which makes logical sense. From this, the cumulative distribution function is defined and it is simple to find the percent chance that the range will be positive. As long as the range is zero (the distance from the touchdown point to the end of the runway is greater than the ground roll distance), there will be a successful landing. The total probability is found by multiplying the transverse and longitudinal probabilities together.

sec.title: Probability of rescue (P3) safety
sec.p: The safety of phase 3 solely depends on the proximity of the rescue services. This includes the nearest hospital and fire department. Due to this, the formulation for the P3 value is extremely simple (19)P3=g(dh+dfg)bestg(dh+dfg) where dh≡distance to hospital, df≡distance to fire department. If there is a fire department located at the airport, df=1. Every landing site will have a dh+df value. Here, g(dh+dfg)best represents the landing site being considered that has the best (lowest) value. Once they have all been normalized by this optimal value, they are ready for the algorithm.

sec.title: Polar plot presentation – abort roses
sec.p: There is a need to present the results in a new, practical way for pilots to utilize. The true test for research in distress management is if the information can be used in a practical sense. If the results stay purely theoretical, then it becomes irrelevant. That is why a primary goal of this project was not just to create an innovative program to use in-flight optimization, but to be presented in a simple, innovative way. This task was accomplished by the abort rose and the emergency abort rose polar plots developed. For every flight, the pilot would have access to each of these plots. The Weibull K value radially varies in the plot. The angle of the plot represents the percent completion of the flight. Case study no. 2 in the following sections uses polar plot representation.

sec.title: Case study no. 1. West coast distress event
sec.p:
For this case study, the following scenario is considered: A transport category aircraft encountered an in-flight right-wing structural damage while on a descent out of flight level 200 (20,000 feet) into San Francisco International Airport (KSFO), as marked in sectional charts, (Figure 6). Indicated airspeed was 340 knots. The aircraft had departed New York LaGuardia airport (KLGA) with no problems; however sudden changes occurred while passing north of Stockton (KSCT). Based on the co-pilot’s visual inspection, the damage is located on outer board wing. The pilots are trying to maximize safe outcome probability following this scenario. The transport aircraft landing distance requirements reduced the possible landing sites to the following list: San Francisco (KSFO), Oakland (KOAK), San Jose (KSJC), Moffett Federal (KNUQ), Stockton (KSCK), Sacramento (KSMF), Travis (KSUU), McClellan (KMHR) and Mather (KMHR). Figure 6.
Case study no.1 scenario showing the flight ground track prior to failure and the airports. Figure 7.
Effects of different failures rates k (decreasing, constant, increasing) on Weibull distribution for the same f(x)=kλ(xλ)k-1e-(x/λ)k mean value. Table 1.
Phase 2 and phase 3 success probabilities.
Airport Phase 2 Phase 3
KSMF 0.95 0.8
KMHR 0.95 0.6

Using DART-MSOP architecture’s statistical based algorithm-1 first, the best landing site is identified to be Sacramento International (KSMF), a mid-sized airport with all the standard facilities and the best abort site to be Mather Field (KMHR), a decommissioned military base with limited rescue recovery facilities. A landing at Stockton is also suggested by algorithm-1 however since it requires spiraling down trajectories this site was not included as a possible landing site in our case study no.1. Our simulation takes Sacramento to be the destination and Mather as the possible abort airport in computing success probability of the entire flight which includes phases 1, 2 and 3. Weibull probability distribution is assumed for this numerical case study. The probabilities for phases 2 and 3 are selected based on the characteristics of the airports. The airports both have long, wide runways therefore in this case study 1, we assigned phase 2 probabilities to be identical. The critical difference is in the phase 3 characteristics, due to the lack of ambulance and fire suppression personnel at Mather Field. Assumed probabilities are listed in Table 1.

Surprisingly, this minor difference makes the overall safety of flying to Sacramento International Airport higher than flying to Mather Airport, even though the distance is longer. This undoubtedly is related to the path safety metric, which is very flat throughout most of its domain. In other words, the safety metric implies that if the airplane is likely to reach the landing site, then a few kilometers one way or the other is not very important for the safety of the mission. This seems likely to be true for many failure modes, though not necessarily for all, insufficient fuel being a notable example. In any case, this result implies that simply choosing the nearest airport may not be as effective as one might think.

One point of note is that the Weibull distribution’s parameters are not independent. In the Gaussian distribution, the first and second moments each have their own independent parameters in the distribution function, whereas in the Weibull distribution, the moments are each functions of both parameters. Hence, changing the distribution size parameter (λ), changes the mean, but so does changing K, the failure rate. The same is true of the variance. For this reason, the parameters are chosen based on the mean, rather than the distribution size parameter. Since the relationship between the mean and λ changes with K, test cases with the same mean and different failure rates (K) will have different λ values. The mean and failure rates chosen for this study are listed as follows (Table 2). Table 2.
Weibull distribution mean value and failure.
Mean Failure rate (K)
120,000 0.5
140,000 1.0
160,000 2.0

With three values for each parameter, nine test cases are required to cover all the permutations. The failure rates chosen here represent decreasing, constant, and increasing failure rates, respectively (0.5, 1.0, and 2.0). The means were chosen as a representative set of values to illustrate the behavior of the algorithm with changing mean. Hence, the parameters cover a representative portion of the valid domain of the parameters.

Looking at the data, a few notable points appear. First, the plan with the lowest probability of success has a decreasing failure rate and the lowest mean. For the mean, a low-abort probability corresponds to a higher probability of abort and hence a stronger weighting toward the abort safety, which is much lower than the nominal safety. Therefore, there is a lower overall safety. Looking at the failure rate with this same weighting paradigm, it becomes clear why a decreasing failure rate would result in a less safe flight plan. Since most of the failure probability density is in the early part of the path, the probability of aborting is higher than for an increasing failure rate with the same mean. This results in weighting the overall safety more toward the less safe abort airport. In fact, the overall success probability very closely mirrors Figure 9(a), the probability of landing at KSMF. This would seem to suggest that the probability of landing at KSMF is the dominant factor in the overall safety. Figure 8.
DART-MSOP architecture’s algorithm-2 path following coordinates optimization constrains used turn radius and flight path angle.1

When the nominal path is attracted to the abort airport, three things happen. First, the average-abort path length decreases. This increases the safety of abort paths in general, and favors further biasing. Second, the aircraft spends more time (or distance) in a region where an abort is possible, and hence the overall probability that an abort will occur increases. This tends to shift the average safety more toward the abort airport, which decreases overall safety. Hence, this effect would favor less biasing. Third, it lengthens the nominal path, which will reduce the nominal path safety and hence the overall path safety. Since the safety metric is relatively flat, one would expect that this effect would be rather weak. With respect to the three effects, two favors less biasing and one favors more. Judging by the optimal flight paths generated, the factors favoring less biasing would seem to be the strongest, at least with these parameters.

Figure 9 shows that the optimized path is very similar to the unoptimized path. The probability of landing at KSMF actually increases slightly in several cases, the exact opposite of what happens when the expected path length is used as the optimization metric. This suggests that the integration of airport parameters in the optimization has a significant effect on the path versus an expected path length-based approach. It also suggests that it is essential to use an abort probability model that can capture the change in the overall probability of abort with changing path. When the path gets longer, there is a higher chance of an abort occurring. This is an intuitively apparent point, but the result shows more rigorously that this is an important effect. Figure 9.
(a): Successful completion probability of all three phases of flight at Sacramento International for various failure rates. (b): Effects of optimizing the in-flight (phase-1 portion of trajectory) using DART-MSOP algorithm-2 under flight path angle and turn radius constraints.

A notable fact is that if the nominal path is initialized as a straight line (with initial and approach turns, of course), any change must increase the length of the nominal path, and therefore decrease the safety. The fact that the probability of landing at KSMF increases at all indicates that the initial path is not a straight line. In fact, the initialization does not use a straight line due to the process in which the waypoints are initialized. It is very close to a straight line at initialization, so the fact that the optimization is making it straighter suggests that the initialization should be rewritten to ensure that the initial path is the shortest possible path from the distress event to the nominal airport.

Figure 10 shows the trend as K is swept from 0.5 to 2.0, illustrating the change in optimal path for decreasing (black), constant (gray), and increasing (light gray) failure rates. In the decreasing failure case, most of the probability mass lies early in the path, so biasing toward the abort airport is more helpful and the optimal path is more bent. As K increases, the probability mass moves toward the end of the path, reducing the advantage of biasing the path toward the abort airport. This is shown clearly in the figure as the path straightens with increasing K (moving to the left). This result shows that the algorithm is working, as expected in this regime. Figure 10.
Safe flight paths for various failure rates, Case study no. 1 results.

sec.title: Case study no. 2. East coast distress event and abort rose representation
sec.p:
An east coast flight traveling from Benedicta, ME to Presque Isle, ME the plots would be as seen in Figures 11 and 12. The pilot starts at Benedicta or 0° and as the flight progresses, the plane flies over the various checkpoints (Sherman, North Sherman, Island Falls, etc.). If the distress event occurs over Island Falls and has a damage event that does not indicate that it will get better or worse (K = 1), then the pilot would simply need to find Island Falls and locate the point at K = 1. The pilot would see a green dot and quickly know there is a 30–40% chance of abort. From this point, the pilot would also be able to find the effect that the optimization program would have if it is run. The pilot would also be able to see how this information changes with time. If the decision is made to continue to the final destination, the pilot would have access to the percent chance of abort for the rest of the flight. If another distress event occurs over Merrill that increases the K value to 2, the pilot would simply have to find that point on the abort rose. If they were to continue on their path as far as Saint Croix, their initial abort opportunity would have virtually vanished. There is no more data after Saint Croix because the initial abort window has closed. Figure 11.
Northern Maine abort rose.
Figure 12.
Northern Maine emergency abort rose.

In certain cases, an emergency abort rose can exist. This would be in a situation where there was another possible abort site after passing the abort site from the abort rose. The emergency abort site in Figure 12 is actually an unused runway that could provide a safe landing. The phase 2 and phase 3 values of this runway are not very good; however, if the situation gets much worse it could be a possibility. This would be the perfect opportunity for the pilot to use the DART–MSOP program to help determine if they should land in the nearby, poorly facilitated landing site or the farther well-facilitated one.

In this way, the DART roses compile the useful results for every distress possibility in a given flight. No matter what happens during the flight or how the damage evolves, these roses will provide useful information. This universal applicability for a flight is innovative, given the ease of use and the magnitude of information provided in a single plot.

sec.title: Concluding remarks
sec.p:
This article developed a unique, dynamic landing safety metric for use in emergency flight path planning. Previous methods consider only fully functional landing sites and only consider distance to the site. This algorithm adds several layers of complexity for a more complete model. Two landing sites are considered when shaping the trajectory, a nominal and abort. The algorithm considers runway length, landing distance, and evacuation when computing the safety of landing sites. Based on these safety probabilities and through optimization, a safest possible path is defined. Two realistic case studies were carried out. The first simulated a flight in Northern California (Figure 13) and the second simulated a flight in Northern Maine (Figures 11 and 12). These test cases showed that the algorithm is capable of evaluating flight plans using the safety metric and abort model. Results show that the nearest landing sites may not always be the safest. This shows the benefit of having access to the results of DART–MSOP when deciding a flight plan after a distress event. These results were presented in a useful format with the abort rose and the emergency abort rose. These polar plots compile every distress possibility for a given flight in a compact and easy to use way. For any possible distress event, a pilot can find out what the percent chance of abort is. If that distress event becomes better or worse, the pilot can once again use that same chart to find out how this changes the percent chance that an abort should be made. In this way, the abort rose and the emergency abort rose could be a potentially invaluable tool to future pilots that are making high-pressure decisions in distress situations. Figure 13.
Northern California abort rose.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by NASA cooperative [grant number NNX08AB96A].

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The authors also acknowledge helpful comments from DynaaTECC (Dynamics, Acoustics, Aeroelasticity, Theory, Experiments, Computations, and Controls) research group members in particular Israel Lopez.
